hints.content: Because each square has an area of $1$ square unit, we can count the shaded squares to find the area.

Add the $\green {8\text{ square units}}$ and $\blue {4 \text{ square units}}$.  

$\green{8} + \blue {4} = 12$
The area of the shape is $12$ square units.

hints.content: ŤŢĥȟéè ďđíìśŝťțáàńňćĉéè áàŕřóòúùńňďđ áà ćĉĺľóòśŝéèďđ ḟíìĝǧúùŕřéè íìśŝ ćĉáàĺľĺľéèďđ íìťțśŝ ṕṗéèŕříìḿṁéèťțéèŕř.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1533d5faa174de926f19ace983d0ec5fac2db9fe)  

The sum of all the known lengths is:

$\redC{7} + \greenD{3} + \gray{4} + \blueD{7} = \maroonD{{21}\,\text{cm}}$.

The total perimeter is $26\,\text{cm}$.  

Subtract the known lengths from  $26\,\text{cm}$ to find the missing length.  

$26 - \maroonD{21} = \purpleC{5\,\text{ cm}}$
The missing side length is  $\purpleC {5\,\text{cm}}$.

hints.content:
Move the dot all the way to the right:

[[☃ interaction 1]]

Wowwwweeee! We just made a rectangle!
The original triangle has $\dfrac{1}{2}$ the area of the rectangle we just made.

$\text{Area of rectangle} = \text{base} \times \text{height}$

$\text{Area of triangle} = \dfrac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height}$

$\phantom{\text{Area of triangle}} = \dfrac{1}{2} \times 6 \times 21$

$\phantom{\text{Area of triangle}} = 3 \times 21$

$\phantom{\text{Area of triangle}} = 63$
The triangle has an area of $63$ units$^2$.

hints.content:
We can enclose this polygon in a square with area $7 \times 7 =49$.   
![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/676bdbc413b1215e51d06e6ebfd1650555012180.png)

The areas of the four right triangles are:  

$\qquad \purple{\dfrac{6 \cdot 3}{2}} = \purple9$  

$\qquad \pink{\dfrac{6 \cdot4}{2}} = \pink{12}$  

$\qquad \green{\dfrac{1 \cdot1}{2}} = \green{0.5}$  

$\qquad \red{\dfrac{6 \cdot 1}{2}} = \red{3}$

The area of the original polygon can be found by subtracting the area of the right triangles from the area of the square.  

$49-\purple9-\pink{12}-\green{0.5}-\red {3}=\blue{24.5}$
**The polygon has an area of $24.5 \text{ units}^2$.**

hints.content: ŤŢĥȟíìśŝ ḟíìĝǧúùŕřéè íìśŝ áà ʠúùáàďđŕříìĺľáàťțéèŕřáàĺľ ẃẁíìťțĥȟ áà ṕṗáàíìŕř óòḟ ṕṗáàŕřáàĺľĺľéèĺľ śŝíìďđéèśŝ (ťțĥȟéè ťțóòṕṗ áàńňďđ ƀḃóòťțťțóòḿṁ śŝíìďđéèśŝ), śŝóò íìťț'śŝ áà ťțŕřáàṕṗéèźžóòíìďđ.
$\text{Area of a trapezoid} = \dfrac12 \cdot (b_1 + b_2) \cdot h$

Now use this formula to calculate the trapezoid's area.

 $b_1 = 3$

 $b_2 = 2$

 $h = 2$

 $A = \dfrac12 \cdot (3 + 2) \cdot 2 = 5$

hints.content:
This shape is made up of a square at the center and two right triangles on the sides.   
![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/69631e26f7159924e2f362d48be52a9a88f47634.png)

We know the base of the shape is $2.5$ units wide, so we can form a square at the center of the shape with side length $2.5$ units.

${\text{Area}}=2.5\cdot2.5=\blue{6.25}\text{ units}^2$

We can combine the two right triangles to form another square:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/be1bc5772705af1eca32f8a77521f555510012fc.png)  
  
${\text{Area}}=2.5\cdot2.5=\red{6.25}\text{ units}^2$.

To find the total area of the shape, we can combine the two areas we found:  

$\blue6\blue.\blue2\blue5+\red6\red.\red2\red5=\purple1\purple2\purple.\purple5$.
Jimmy needs enough paint to cover $12.5\text{ units}^2$ of area.

question.content:
**Find the area of the shape shown below.**

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6ccea7bbc3b7fbfd905bb469600a697c97e062dc)
  
 [[☃ input-number 1]] $\text{units}^2$

hints.content: ĹĽéèťț'śŝ śŝéèťț úùṕṗ áàńň éèʠúùáàťțíìóòńň úùśŝíìńňĝǧ ťțĥȟéè ḟóòŕřḿṁúùĺľáà ḟóòŕř ťțĥȟéè áàŕřéèáà óòḟ áà ṕṗáàŕřáàĺľĺľéèĺľóòĝǧŕřáàḿṁ.

$\begin{align} \text{Area of a parallelogram} &=  \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\
21&= 7 \cdot h \\\\
21&= 7h \\\\
\dfrac{21}{\blueD{7}}&= \dfrac{7h}{\blueD{7}} ~~~~~~~\text{divide both sides by } {\blueD{ 7}}\\\\
\dfrac{21}{\blueD{7}}&= \dfrac{\cancel{7}h}{\blueD{\cancel{7}}}\\\\
h &=\dfrac{21}{\blueD{7}}\\\\
h &=3\end{align}$

The answer:

$h = 3$ units

question.content:
**Suppose the radius of a circle is $\color{purple}{1}$. What is its circumference?**  
*Either enter an exact answer in terms of $\pi$ or use $3.14$ for $\pi$ and enter your answer as a decimal.*


[[☃ expression 1]]

hints.content: ![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/138686173c14d10ab5472974e2bc579395c9d3f8)

First, find the radius:

 $ \begin{align} r &= \dfrac d2 \\\\ r &= \dfrac{\color{green}{16}}{2} \\\\ r &= \color{purple}{8} \end{align} $

The equation for the area of a circle is:

 $K = \pi r^2$
$K = \pi \cdot \color{purple}{8}^2$

$K = \color{red}{64\pi}$

 ![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f97131fb7d65f1ef3566ecd9cd99e53b563d32ce)

question.content:
**Find the area of a circle with a diameter of $\color{green}{16}$.**  
*Either enter an exact answer in terms of $\pi$ or use $3.14$ for $\pi$ and enter your answer as a decimal.*


[[☃ expression 1]] units$^2$

hints.content:
###Getting started

We want to find the arc length of $\dfrac12$ of a circle. Let's start by finding the circumference of the circle.

###Step 1: Find the radius

${\text{Radius}} = \dfrac{\text{Diameter}}{2} = \dfrac{12}{2} = 6$

###Step 2: Find the circumference of the circle

$\begin{align} \text{Circumference of the circle} &=  2\pi r \\\\ &= 2\pi\cdot 6 \\\\
&= 6 \cdot2\pi \\\\
&= \goldD{12\pi} \\\\
\end{align}$

###Step 3: Find the arc length of $\dfrac12$ of the circle


$\begin{align} \text{Circumference of } \dfrac12  \text{ of the circle} &=  \dfrac12 \cdot \goldD{12\pi} \\\\ 
&= \dfrac{12}{2}\pi \\\\
&= 6\pi \\\\
\end{align}$

###The answer

The arc length of the semicircle is $6\pi$ units.

*(Note that we could also multiply $6$ by $3.14$ to get $18.84$ units.)*
